testimony: Mr Valus, you may call your witness - your client rather.
As it pleases Mr Chairman, I call Ginotry Danster.  He will testify in Xhosa, that is his mother tongue.
Yes, do we have the facilities for this?
Yes, Mr Chairman, we've organised that already.
Is there a microphone there for him sit?
Mr Chairman, sorry to interrupt, may I enquire whether the Committee has come to any decision concerning the evidence of Mr Coetzee or whether that would be left over until later?
Mr Danster, are you prepared to take the oath?

Thank you Mr Chairman.
	Mr Danster, you joined the South African Police in April 1978?
After your basic training was finished, where were you stationed?
What department in Port Elizabeth or the South African Police?
During 1981, you went to Bloemfontein to fetch a terrorist, is that correct?

I don't think you should do that you know.  I think that where matters are contested, try and avoid putting leading questions to him where it is likely that that evidence might be challenged.  So rather put your questions in such a way that they don't suggest the answer.
As it pleases Mr Chairman, I will.
Where in Port Elizabeth were you stationed?
What was the nature of the work that you did whilst you were in the security police?
We were investigating people who break laws in accordance with politics.
Under whom did you work at that time?
And were you in Port Elizabeth all the time or did they move you around?
Did you drive government vehicles, police vehicles?
Do you know a man who was detained one Kondile?
How did you come to know him?
We went to fetch him from Bloemfontein.
Captain du Plessis, Buzani and Raath.
Yes, you may proceed from there.

Thank you Mr Chairman.
	When was that when you went to fetch Mr Kondile, more or less that you can remember?
Where did you go to in Bloemfontein when you went to fetch him?
We went to the security police offices.
We then slept over, got up in the morning and we left with a black policeman to the police station in Bloemfontein.
Did this policeman lead you to anyone?
We were given a command by Captain du Plessis to go and fetch Sizwe from where he was detained.
We booked him out and we took him to the security police offices.
Do you know what happened with Mr Kondile after this?
We took him back to Port Elizabeth.
We took him to Captain du Plessis's office.
Could I just ask Mr Danster, what was Sizwe Kondile's physical demean at the time, was he injured, was he fine?  What was your observation?
He was all right, in good health.
Mr Danster tell me, how many motor vehicles went to Bloemfontein to fetch him?
What kind of car was it?
And how many of you returned together?
It Buzani, Raath, Captain du Plessis, Sizwe, Kondile and myself.
On of the reasons I asked the question is, if you look at Volume 2 page 178, there is an entry here at Humansdorp, Friday the 10th of July 1981.

Sorry, give me a minute, I know I saw an entry and I just want to see if it's the same one, yes, it's the same one - that he was admitted to the cells and his nose was bleeding.  Is that on the day that you fetched him, no?
I just want to be absolutely clear, give me the names of the people you said.  Yourself, Mr du Plessis, Mr Kondile and who else?
Yes, you returned in the same car in which you had gone up?
We had a problem in the car, they fetched another car.  I will tell you the people who fetched the car.
My questions was, did you return in the same car from Bloemfontein in which you had gone to Bloemfontein?
I think we had a problem with that car, it heated up and we had to borrow another car.
I see, so you borrowed another car.  And the car the you borrowed, is that now a Datsun?
You testified that Kondile was taken to Mr du Plessis office in Port Elizabeth, can you tell the Commission what happened there?
We took him out of the car, we covered his head with a balaclava, he was handcuffed.  It must have been in the afternoon, later afternoon as people had already left from the offices.
We then went into the office and Mr du Plessis asked him a few questions.  After that he made a call and made arrangements for him to be detained.
Do you know where this place was that was arranged for detention?

I didn't go personally however I was there when arrangements were being made.
MR ROUX
Did you hear the place that was mentioned?
He phoned Mr Jonker in Jeffrey's Bay.
What was your part with Mr Kondile then again?  When did you become involved with him again?
Mr du Plessis had given us the information that we were supposed to get from him, this was written on paper.
When did you receive the paper?

After Kondile had been detained in Jeffrey's Bay, Raath, Buzani and myself together with Mr du Plessis were given orders and we were given that piece of paper written the details which we were to ask Mr Kondile.
Mr Danster, let us go back to the first day where you arrived from Bloemfontein.  After this phone call to make arrangements for his detention, what did you do?
And the next time you had anything to do with Mr Kondile, was in Jeffrey's Bay?
I was given an order to stay in Jeffrey's Bay for a while by Captain du Plessis.
I think the question was: when, how many days after you had brought Mr Kondile to Port Elizabeth, did you next ...[intervention]
I'm not sure but it was soon after we'd come back with him.
In Jeffrey's Bay, were you alone - the only person who was instructed to go to Jeffrey's Bay to Mr Kondile?
Yes.  No, it was Raath and myself.
Did you follow the instructions that were given to you in connection with the questionnaire that you received?
What was the result of the questions?  Did Mr Kondile answer the questions?
We would give him a pen and a paper to write down the answers.
Did he give you all the answers to all the questions?
We took all the answers and gave them to Mr du Plessis.  After he arrived in Jeffrey's Bay he said these were not the answers, this is not the information that he'd wanted.
Before we continue, just tell the Commission, where was Mr Kondile held and where were the questions asked?
He was in the office that was emptied for us to use.
If he wasn't asked, where was he detained?
Now, you testified that Mr du Plessis wasn't satisfied with the answers, what was his reaction?
Captain du Plessis arrived with his colleagues.

He said: "When you are investigating a terrorist, this is how you go about it, you have got to get the truth".  He then showed us the way you retrieve information from a terrorist.  Sizwe was tied at the knees.  He said I must handcuff him from the back.  We then made him lie on the floor and we put a sack on him - we refer to it as: "the prisoner's bag".
What did you describe the bag as?

Prisoner's bag - Prisoner's property bag. We put this over his head and you have to put this on very tightly so that he can't breach and then at the same time there was a small machine ...[intervention]
The interpreter could not hear the speaker.

This machine has a crank handle with two wires.  When you use this crank handle it's very painful to the victim.  That is how information was retrieved from a prisoner.  Every time we saw that he's suffocating we took the bag off his head and then he'd be asked questions.

Sorry, if I can interrupt you there.  You described now to the Commission, the prisoner bag and you described the machine with the crank handle, was this now what was used by Mr du Plessis to show you how to get information out of or how to get the truth out of somebody?
Was Mr du Plessis alone there while he showed you this?
It was himself, Raath and myself.  Gideon Niewoudt and Roelofse were there, also Buzani.
Well, before we get to that, just explain to me what role does this electrical box play, this cranking business, how was that used?
This machine when used, is very, very painful, you will give us any information that we want from you because of the pain.
How does it give the pain?  What does the machine do?
Is the word choke or is the word shock?
While we're on that subject, can you just describe to the Commission how this machine operates?

U turn it, there's a handle and the second person takes the two wires, puts it on your body wherever they choose to.  If you wind this machine to be more powerful you splash water on the victim and then the victim will give us the information because of the pain.
Let's try and confine yourself as to what you did on this particular occasion, do you understand?  Tell us who put this bag on Mr Kondile's head?
We all took part in that.
Who operated that crank handle of this machine?
The Captain showed us how to use the machine.
My question is, who did it, who handled the crank handle on Mr Kondile?
We all used the machine and turned the crank handle.
When one is turning the handle, the other person would have to put the wires on his body, whoever it was.
So, do I gather from you that all of you, at some time or the other turned the crank handle and all of you at some time or the other, held the wires to the body of Mr Kondile?
Yes, and who did the questioning?
What was Mr Kondile's attitude towards co-operating during the initial weeks?
During the initial weeks of detainment in Jeffrey's Bay.
That's a leading question, the witness never said that ...[indistinct] was initially detained for weeks in Jeffrey's Bay.
I'll correct that.  How long was Mr Kondile detained in Jeffrey's Bay?
Quite a long time, I think plus minus 12 weeks.
During the initial weeks of his detainment, what was his attitude towards co-operation?
Despite the use of little machine you were talking about?
We used a car tube and the machine.
Can you tell the commission about this car tube you just mentioned?

The car tube is round, you cut it, close it on the top so that there is no air for the victim and he would struggle to breath.  In the same instance the machine is being used on his body that gives pain to the victim and it tires him quickly.  We'd then remove the tube after you'd collapsed and feinted, to give him a bit of air.
Was the tube put around the head of Mr Kondile as well?
What happened to the prisoner's bag, would that stay on his head while the tube is put around his face or was the bag removed?

Now, you were asked whether Mr Kondile co-operated at first by answering questions and you said that at first he did not co-operate and my question to you was, is that despite the use of these methods on him that he did not co-operate?
He gave us a lot of information after we had tortured him.
Did Captain du Plessis play any role after that first display of how to get information or the truth out of the person?
He would get in touch with us from day to day.
You know that doesn't seem to be an answer to the question.
What was the purpose of him getting in touch with you?
He wanted information, answers of what we'd asked Mr Kondile.  He wanted to know if we were getting the information that we'd targeted.
Did he give any instructions regarding the fact that in the initial weeks Mr Kondile wasn't so co-operative?
In the initial weeks you testified Mr Kondile wasn't so co-operative, did Mr du Plessis say anything about this?
Tell the commission if you can remember.
He said that we should not beat him up.
Did he afford a reason for that?
Because he does not want a: "Steve Biko" case again.
What do you know about Mr van Rensburg in regard to Mr Kondile?
As Mr van Rensburg was the head, he would come to Jeffrey's Bay with Mr Erasmus.
If you say he would come to Jeffrey's Bay, where in Jeffrey's Bay?
He would come to the room where we were interrogating Sizwe.
Was Mr van Rensburg or Erasmus ever present while there was an interrogation taking place?
They would get there and talk to Captain du Plessis.
...[inaudible] present when Mr Kondile was being interrogated, that's the question.
No, they would just go there to assess the progress.
What was the purpose of the interrogation?
The orders by Captain du Plessis were such ...[inaudible] He wanted to know about ammunition, people who were trained guerrillas.
Sorry Mr Chairman, just help - sorry Mr Chairman, can I be or assistance, it's not ammunition it's about weapons, not ammunition but weapons.  Thank you.
What do you know about armed caches?
We were asking him about weapons and wanted to know where the weapons were in South Africa, where they were hidden.
Did this interrogation and torture eventually succeed?
Do you know about any pointing out?
After he'd given us certain information, we left for East London, from East London we went to Umtata.  Can I carry on?

In Umtata, according to the information we got from Sizwe, we were with three East London members and we had to go and arrest two men that worked in the bank.  However, as South African Police, we did not have the right to go and arrest people in the Transkei.
	Mr du Plessis then spoke to an officer that was there - that took a while.  This officer then had to go and arrest these two people in the bank.  These two people must have been told that there were police in the bank and they ran away. 
	They then went to Butterworth.  These two men in Butterworth being followed by two detectives.  The one police got injured even a woman policeman.  They then ran away towards McCLear with a car.  There was a roadblock in South Africa.  Those two men ...[intervention]
Sorry, Mr Dunster, the interpreter couldn't hear your previous sentence.

These two men that had shot the woman police and the one male police took their car, used it to get away.  There was a roadblock and when they got there they started shooting, two people were injured.

Mr Danster, if I can just interrupt you there.
	Mr Chairman, I don't know if this is so relevant to the application at this stage, if I maybe can get back to Mr Kondile.
The speaker's microphone is not on.
Yes, one doesn't know whether he witnessed all this or he's repeating what he'd been told by somebody else and even if he did see it, I don't know what it's relevance is to this case.
I was actually - my learned colleagues asked me to ask this.  I didn't intend to examine him like this or lead him on this, I'd rather go back to Mr Kondile specifically.
If I might just ask, having hear this evidence, where were you all of this time?  Did you go to East London, did you go to Umtata?  Did you get as far as the roadblock at McClear?
If we had not gone with Sizwe to the bank, these people would not have been shot, they would not have run away in the first place.
But you personally, you were there, that's really what I want to know?
Yes, I was there both times.
Was Mr Kondile - do you know anything about Mr Kondile tempted to being turned?
What happened?  Did you return after this attempt to arrest those people, did you return to Jeffrey's Bay?
I think the Judge was asking me a question, I didn't hear him.
After you went to arrest these two people in Umtata, did you return to Jeffrey's Bay?
All of you, including Mr Kondile?
What is the next thing of any importance that happened in which you were involved?
Mr du Plessis tried to get Sizwe to work for the police.
What month are we now talking about?
I couldn't tell you the month but it was after a while.
And this was after you had returned to Jeffrey's Bay from Umtata?
What was Mr Kondile's reaction to this attempt?
Sizwe response was that Chris Hani trusts him or trusted him.  He could never work for the police, he'd rather be charged and go to court but he would never work for the police.
You heard the testimony of the applicants, especially Mr du Plessis who testified about a note being found, do you know anything about this note that was testified here about?
Mr Danster, ever when Mr Kondile would have been in the shower in Jeffrey's Bay, where would the people who were instructed to guard him be when he was in the shower?
He showered in his shower, they locked the door and the bars.
Then where would you be at that time?

I would be in the office.
Would there be anybody in the place where he was being guarded? - I believe it was a barracks or something.
He'd be alone in the cell, there would be nobody else there.
Let's just talk about the questioning of Mr Kondile.  You say that you were given a piece of paper by Mr du Plessis?
That paper contained the kind of questions that you were to put to Mr Kondile, is that right?
In what language did you communicate with Mr Kondile?
When you talked to Mr Kondile, did you talk to him in English?
I'd speak both English and Xhosa.
And did Mr Raath have anything to do with questioning?
Yes, he would ask in Afrikaans.
In what language would Mr Kondile reply?
Sizwe would speak to me and I would interpret for Raath.
In what language would Mr du Plessis talk to Kondile?
And would Mr Kondile reply in English?
Just to sum up, during this whole period of detention, who were all the people involved in the interrogation and torture of Mr Kondile?
Perhaps he could if necessary, split it up, who was involved in the interrogation and who was involved in the torture and if they were involved in both, tell us they were involved in both.
I will name them as follows: Captain du Plessis, Captain Roelofse, Niewoudt, Buzani, Raath and myself.
Were any people from East London involved?
There were people from East London that arrived.
When the detectives from East London arrived, we then withdrew from investigating the matter, they interrogated Sizwe themselves.
Did he give answers to them?
Were you present at that stage when they interrogated him?
Now you told us that Mr du Plessis told you that you must not beat him up, do you remember that?
Had he already been beaten at that stage?
He'd been tortured but he said that we must not hit him physically or bang him against the wall so that there are marks on his body, external wounds.
Just repeat that, you must not beat him up or bang him against the wall?  Are those his words?
Yes, he said we must not beat him up so that there are marks on his body.
No, you also used the words: "or bang him against the wall".
Yes, he said that he must not be banged against the wall.
Now, had anybody tried to beat him up or bang him against the wall?
And have you seen anybody beat Mr Kondile?
No assault took place in your presence?
Did Mr Kondile ever complain to you that he had been assaulted?
No, he never complained to me.
All right.  Are there any other questions you wish to put?

If I could just clarify very quickly.  The last few answer you gave when the Chairman asked about assaults, you are really talking about the beating and banging against the wall as opposed to the torture that we spoke about earlier - just for clarity.
Yes, there's a difference.  When you bang someone against the wall or beat him up with your fists or something, there would be marks on the body.
You mentioned now, the names of du Plessis, Raath, Niewoudt, Roelofse, Buzani and yourself, what was the role that Mr Roelofse played?
He would come from time to time, not frequently and he would help in the interrogation.
Did he ever actively take part in the torturing?
If I remember correctly, I think twice he took part.
And the other people you mentioned today, what was their position to actively taking part in torturing?
Niewoudt and Roelofse would come together twice, they would ask questions.  They must have used the torturing machine twice.
What can you remember in regard to the sleep that Mr Kondile had during his period of detention?
Could you repeat your question please.
What can you remember in regard to Mr Kondile's sleeping habits during the period of detention?
Did Mr Kondile sleep during the day or did he sleep during the night?
After we had interrogated him and we would go to sleep, he would sleep as well.
And to your knowledge, did he have any difficulty sleeping?
I don't know what you mean, please clarify your question.
Was the interrogation done at night or during the day?
Sometimes we would deprive him of sleep so that he would tire.
Can you remember anything about a doctor involved in this case?
There's an old man that arrived there and apparently he was a doctor, a white man. We were then given orders just to ask him questions and not to ill-treat him.  He got some medication, tablets.
Who was the person who was giving these orders?
Do you know a man called Dirk Coetzee?
Yes, I met him once before.
Can you tell the Commission if Dirk Coetzee had anything to do with this case.

When we were investigating the matter Captain du Plessis said that Sizwe Kondile was a top terrorist from the Eastern Cape.  The Pretoria anti-terrorist squad would come as well to get information.
	Dirk then arrived, he was with Mr van Rensburg and Captain du Plessis was in Jeffrey's Bay.  They spoke or talked at the side - the two of them, after that the gentlemen left - Coetzee.
Did you at that stage already know that the person was Dirk Coetzee?
When did you find that out?

After a while when I already stopped working for the police.  I saw an article in the newspaper, I saw his face in the newspaper and I then remember that it's the man that had arrived at Jeffrey's Bay.
Do you know anything about Komatie ...[intervention]
Could you kindly stop for a minute.  You said you saw this person Coetzee with van Rensburg, is that correct?
He was with Mr van Rensburg.
Yes.  And then you immediately continued and said Mr du Plessis was in Jeffrey's Bay.
Yes, he was in Jeffrey's Bay.
And did Mr Coetzee talk to van Rensburg or did he talk to du Plessis or were the three of them together, what was the position?
The three of them were talking at the side.
Did they visit the cells or the room where Kondile was kept?
In the room that we were sitting in.
The two of them arrived and Captain du Plessis was inside.
Was he already inside with Kondile?
And at that stage, were you inside too?
So in the end the three of them and you and Raath and Kondile were all present in this room?
Did they ask anything from Mr Kondile at that stage?
They did not ask him any questions, they read what he had written.
Did anybody ask him whether he's well or whether there's anything wrong?
They did not talk to him, they spoke to Captain du Plessis.
What do you know about Komatiepoort?  Do you know anything about Komatiepoort?

After he had given us certain information, Captain du Plessis said himself, Raath and myself must go to Komatiepoort where there were weapons.
	They said that we must stop investigating the matter for a while because we're going to prepare for a journey to Komatiepoort.  I was then taken home and they said that I must wait for him, they are going to fetch me - they did not arrive.  That was during the weekend.  On the Monday when I reported at the office I heard that Raath and Captain du Plessis had already left.  I carried on with my own work at the office and I never saw Sizwe again.
	After a few days Raath came back because I was working with him.  At the security police branch you would work as partners.  When Raath came back he said they had taught Kondile a lesson and he said in Afrikaans: "We taught him a lesson, his brains were splashed all over".  I asked him what he meant because they had left me behind.  
	He asked if I really didn't know what he was talking about.  He did not give me any further information, I made my own conclusions that something drastic had happened.
Do you know the person called Johan Coetzee?
Can you tell if he has anything to do with this case?

He arrived in Port Elizabeth, he was the head of the security police, he was a general at the time.  Before Captain du Plessis left with Sizwe, whilst we were still interrogating him, he said that the case was very important and we had to work hard because Sizwe Kondile was a top terrorist.
	Even Mr Johan Coetzee was going to arrive.  He then arrived together with him in Jeffrey's Bay.  They looked at what Sizwe had written down, they spoke with each other and then they left.
Was that the second time that Coetzee came there? - Johan Coetzee.
You say he came there with Captain du Plessis.
You say Johan Coetzee was a General at that stage, do you know what happened to him in terms of police ranks later on?
After that he was the Commissioner of Police.
I understand that this statement was taken by you by Mr Rajeee Marugaan, is that correct?
Was anything shown to you, any records, any minutes, any statements or affidavits before you made your statement for Mr Marugaan? - in front of him.
Mr Chairman, that's the evidence in chief.
When Mr Coetzee - that's General Coetzee, came down - Johan Coetzee, with Mr du Plessis, where was Kondile at that stage?
He was in the room that we were using.
Did they visit him in the room or did they only pass along?
Sizwe was in the corner tied around the ankles and he was handcuffed to the bed.
I don't want us to have any confusion, was that when General Coetzee visited at that stage or was it when Mr Dirk Coetzee visited?
So you're speaking now about the visit of General Coetzee?
Did the General speak to Mr Kondile?
No, he did not speak to him.
He spoke to Captain du Plessis.

Sorry, Mr Chairman, just one question I forgot to ask.
	Just to finalise, can you just tell the Commission what happened to you in regard to the police force after this incident?
I was transferred to New Brighton enquiries, after that I resigned.
Just the year, what year was that when you were transferred?

Thank you Mr Chairman, that's the examination.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR ROUX
What sort of work are you doing now?
Would you kindly repeat the answer the last question?
Mr Moosa, are there any questions you wish to put to this witness?

Just one or two Mr Chairman.
	The car that you used to come back from Bloemfontein with Mr Kondile, do you remember that?
I don't remember the car because we had a problem with our own car, it heated up.  The following week the car was fetched by Mahote and Adana from Bloemfontein.
The car that you actually used to come back, what happened to that car?
How did you address Mr Kondile, what name did you use?

Thank you, no further questions Mr Chairman.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR MOOSA
When you went to fetch Mr Kondile from Bloemfontein, were you told by anyone how he got to be arrested? - either by a security officer of Mr Kondile himself?
Captain du Plessis said that he'd been arrested close to Lesotho, do you know or was that all?

We got details from Sizwe when we were investigating the matter.  He was going to phone his girlfriend, apparently the phones were not working from the Lesotho side.  He was arrested along the border post.

Do you have anything against Mr du Plessis and Mr Raath to falsely implicate them in the acts of torture that you alleged, except of course for the concession that Mr du Plessis made that he punched him some few punches and slaps?  Do you have anything against them to falsely implicate them in acts of torture?
And that they said Mr Kondile co-operated almost immediately and became an informer, was that a lie?

Finally, the son of Mr Kondile is very proud of the gallant effort and stance that his father took but the only thing that he's critical about regarding you, is that after you resigned you could have gone to the Kondile family which was and still is very well known, and told them confidentially what happened Mr Danster, that is the only part that we are critical about, thank you.  Do you have anything to say about that?

Bond, that's my nickname and it looks like you know me.  As you know, at that time it was difficult, you could not - to take information - the men that have lost their lives for trying to get information to the movement.

...[inaudible] thank you.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR NYOKA
There is something I would like to say.  I would like to address the family.

I'm sure you have waited a long time to hear what happened to Sizwe.  This has been something that has been very heavy on my shoulders, however the truth and lies are not the same.  I would like to apologise to the family.  I did not partake in killing him however, I interrogated him and I ask for forgiveness.

Just one more part Mr Chairperson.
	Can I ask you to go an apologise to them and shake hands with them?
You can do that a little later on.
Mr Booyens, are there any questions you wish to put to this witness?
I certainly have questions for this witness.  Mr Chairman, I don't know whether Mr Jansen's position ...[inaudible]
We will ask him just now.

Certainly.
	Mr Danster, you say you are a builder at present?
So you're not a builder at present, you're a prisoner?
He's a builder by trade or by occupation.

The question was, what is he doing at present M'Lord, he may be a builder by trade - on the premises where he presently is.
	Let's deal with your transfer from the security police.  The reason for that transfer was because there was a small problem about it being alleged that you were involved in some falsified driving licenses, not so?  That's the reason for your transfer, you were in fact found guilty of an offence like that.  I'm not saying you committed it, I'm just saying you were found guilty and then you were transferred, is that correct?
So your transfer from the security police had absolutely nothing to do with your involvement with Mr Kondile, it had something to do with something completely different , is that right?

Let's deal with these cars that you were - the problems with the motor cars and the return from Bloemfontein and so on, I just want to get clarity about that.  You had to borrow a car in Bloemfontein, is that right? - because your P.E. car gave you problems, is that right?
Was that a police car with a radio?
And ultimately that Bloemfontein police car was taken back to Bloemfontein and your P.E. car was returned, is that right?
The point is, the five of you - that's including the four policemen and the deceased, travelled down in the Bloemfontein police car to Port Elizabeth, is that right?
And this Bloemfontein police car, can you remember how long it stayed here before Bloemfontein came to fetch it or before it was taken back to Bloemfontein?
Where was this car, was it at your security headquarters in P.E.? - the Bloemfontein car.
I'm not sure, I think it was taken to P.E. where they kept the police cars.
Yes, not the government garage, the police garage.

So it seems to that for that first week at least you were in P.E. because you even know about the movements with the motor car? - your car being returned, the Bloemfontein car being fetched.  So you were not involved with the deceased at that stage?
As the car was taken - we were using a ...[indistinct], there were cars there that could be used.
That's not the point of the question please Mr Danster.
What are you trying to ask me?

Just answer my questions, don't tell me what to ask you.  You must have been in P.E. because you know that the Bloemfontein car was taken back after about a week.  You were in P.E., you were not in Jeffrey's Bay, is that right?
Okay.  Were you in Jeffrey's Bay right from - well, you came back with the deceased and did you start dealing with the deceased the very next day or two days later, what is the position?
It was not too long a time after we'd come back then we continued with the investigation.
That's what I'm asking you, how is not too long a time?  Was it the next day, two days later, a week later, two weeks later, that's what I want to know.
I cannot remember the exact time that elapsed.
